title: Welcome to My Data Science Portfolio
text:
Welcome to my data science portfolio! This site shows my journey learning data science and analytics. Here you’ll find projects that demonstrate what I’ve learned and discovered.


This portfolio shows my work learning data science. Each project includes:

My code with documentation
Visualizations I created
What I learned and discovered

I built this site using Quarto and host it on GitHub Pages.




Programming: Python, Pandas for data analysis
Visualization: Creating charts with Matplotlib and Seaborn
Data Collection: Getting data from files, websites, and APIs
Analysis: Finding patterns and answering questions with data







Learn how I explore datasets to find interesting patterns and answer questions.



See how I gather data from different sources and prepare it for analysis.



See how I tackle a data science project beginning to end.



Thanks for visiting! Feel free to explore my projects and see what I’m learning.

title: About Me
text:
Greetings:

I’m currently a Junior at BYU studying data science.
I’m interested in studying data science and using it to solve real world problems.
I am currently pursuing a career as a data scientist or a data analyst.
I’m experienced in SQL, C++, C, Python, Pandas, Numpy, and Java. I have previously made a chess game with a corresponding server/client servers, and a Datalog program from scratch.

Goals

In the short-term I hope to improve my understanding of common Data Science tools and improve my usage of htem.
In the long-term I simply want a stable career in teh field of data science.
I want to solve problems that affect every day people and help make their life easier, whether directly or indirectly.

This portfolio showcases my learning progress and projects completed during my data science studies.

title: Data Acquisition Project
text:
Hello there! Welcome to my data science blog! Today I will be teaching you how to scrape your own movie dataset, and then use it to find interesting relations between that movie, its ratings, its revenue, and more! To aid in this example, I will use a project completed by me and my partner. This project involved looking at all movies released by Disney, and finding relationships between their scores, their revenue, and other variables of interest.




This project is relevant because new movies are coming out every month, and we want to if they are worth watching before they come out, and Disney in particular has been producing many movies over the recent years. If we can find trends in what movies will be good or not, we can save ourselves headache in trying to decide if it is worth our time and dime.



This project is interesting because it can show how people have viewed disney and it’s movies over time. Do people see their movies as having gotten better, or worse? Does Disney still have the popularity that it once did? Has it even grown? These are questions we believe are interesting and want to answer.



We hope to find a correlation between factors that might show us in advance if something is worth seeing or if a movie will be worth making for Disney. (We wouldn’t want to expect a sequel only to learn that no one liked the first movie.) This can be done by not only looking at score and revenue of a movie, but by checking what season it was released in, or which director oversaw it.




Now that we have the introduction complete, it is time to start creating our dataset! However, we need to make sure that it is done ethically. Concerning the web scraping for our project, it was ethical to gather our movie data because we abided by the robots.txt and used public websites with public information.
We did this by including a header in our request, thus allowing the website owners to contact us if they didn’t like our scraping, and we abided by all the rules in the robots.txt. For our websites, there was no time delay required, but we still made sure we didn’t overwhelm the website with too many requests at once. If we ever needed a lot of requests, we split up the time between sending those large requests, thus ensuring we only scraped every once in awhile and not constantly. Finally, we didn’t go onto any disallowed websites, but only stayed within accepted domains.



Now that you know how to go about ethically web scraping, what are the actual steps for creating your dataset? Well, concerning our web scraping process, and data collection process in general, were as follows:

Scrape titles and release from website containing all disney movies
Reformat the titles to fit Rotten Tomatoes’s url formula
Created Rotten Tomatoes’s urls using those reformatted titles
Checked the urls to see if they worked, (in other words, if the response code was 200)
If they didn’t we tried multiple methods to modify them into the correct format, and for the unique ones, (like those with a specific ID code), we manually fixed them.
Took each url and scrapped the information we needed from its respective website
Turned placed that information into a Pandas Dataframe
Cleaned that dataframe
Created new columns from old columns as required for our analysis, (such as decade using the year column)
All done! The dataset is clean and ready to be analyzed!

By following these steps, you can make your own dataset and continue on to the next step: Analyzing!
Analysis will be different for each person, since each person will have a different goal and question that they want to answer using their dataset. thus, I cannot give you a step by step guide on how to analyze your dataset, but I can give you some tips.

Find the mean of a specific feature, and track how it changes over time. You can set the boundaries of your analysis as large or as small as you want. You can analyze over a specific year, or analyze over the entire domain, which in this case, would be all the years that Disney released movies. Then, you can choose to look at the mean for each year, or for each decade, if you have a smaller boundary, then you could analyze over months instead. This usually yields interesting results and helps you find trends.
Find correlations between features. Can you predict what one feature will look like if you know another? For our example, if you know the season the movie came out, or who it was directed by, could you predict how much money the movie will make? You could also answer questions such as: Do high scoring movies always make more money?




Now, we will give you some specifics on what we found during our analysis. During this project our most interesting findings were:

Movie ratings appear to be consistently going up each decade (on average), indicating that movies are getting better.
Movies rated R have the lowest revenue amount on average (this may be affected by the low number of R-rated movies).
Movies rated PG-13 have a noticeable but slight average increase in revenue. (Also, revenue is not adjusted for inflation)
TV-14 is the highest-rated film on average, with TV-PG the lowest.

Here are the graphs related to our findings:
  


Concerning our base information, we had a total sample size was 523 movies. We had 13 variables: Title, Audience Score, Critic Score, Revenue, Release Date, Year, Film Rating, Director, Genre, Runtime, Month, Season, and Decade. Six were categorical, and seven were quantitative, and including the release date (year-month-day) in quantitative.
Additionally, here are some of the summary statistics we found regarding our two features of greatest interest Revenue and Score: (We would like to note, that in the case of Rotten Tomatoes, score is split into two categories: Audience Score and Critic Score. This is due to how Rotten Tomatoes has these two separate score categories when scoring movies.)
Audience Score:

count 477.0
mean 61.174004
std 19.130388
min 11.0
25% 46.0
50% 63.0
75% 76.0
max 100.0

Critic Score:

count 359.0
mean 62.649025
std 27.176733
min 0.0
25% 42.0
50% 68.0
75% 86.5
max 100.0

Revenue:

count 221.0
mean 83668368.778281
std 106875556.581597
min 5100.0
25% 17000000.0
50% 50600000.0
75% 100100000.0
max 653000000.0

Additionally, we found that Audience and Critic Score Correlation was 0.72.




Now that you know how to go about a movie analysis project, you can begin your own project! You can choose to use Rotten Tomatoes like we did, or branch out to other movie critic websites. Below, you will find listed our own sources, and sources that you can use as well. You can choose to focus on a different company, or perhaps focus on a genre or movies from certain years. The possibilities are endless!


Sources we used:

Wikipedia-Disney Movies
Rotten Tomatoes

In case you are interested in specifically how we completed this project, or simply want to use our cleaned dataset, then you can find that code here:

Github Repo




Related sources you could use for your own project:

Metacritic
IMDB
Wikipedia-Marvel Movies
Wikipedia-DC Movies

title: About Me
text:
Experience

Vegetable Preparation Chef for Brigham Young University Catering, Sep 2023 - Present

Coordinated with a team of 8 to prepare appetizers and meals for various regular and high-end events

Computer Science 111 Teaching Assistant for Brigham Young University Computer Science Department, Jan 2024 - Apr 2024

Collaborated with a team of 6 to assist students in debugging code and understanding complex coding topics.

Brigham Young University Connect Brand Ambassador Coordinator for Brigham Young University, Sep 2025 - Present

Created a team of Ambassadors for the purpose of promoting BYU Connect, thus improving overall number of mentorship relationships



Areas of Interest

Currently, I am specifically interested in environmental data and how we affect the world around us.
I’m also curious about trends in culture and if those can be predicted.

I am pursuing a career as a data scientist or a data analyst
